data.text: Index
A.  Appendix A - Discharge Check List - Phoenix ward B Appendix B - Discharge from Phoenix Assessment Unit C Appendix C - Electronic Discharge Summary
D Appendix D - Nurse discharge letter
Purpose

The discharge of children from hospital will be individually planned to ensure that the need for continuing care will be met within the community environment, supported by primary care services within the available resources.

1.2. The parents will have acquired knowledge, confidence and practical skills to meet their child's continuing needs for health care in the community, and the need for re-admission will be minimised.
1.3. The parents will be supported and feel secure in continuing to care for their child's care needs in the community, with the support of the primary care team as agreed in the discharge plan.
The Primary Care professionals and family will have received appropriate information from the hospital to enable them to provide continuity of care within the community environment.
Scope
This policy should be adhered to by all staff involved in discharging Children and Young People from the Trust.
Equality and Diversity
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
Discharge Assessment
The nurse will assess the child's and family's individual nursing care/social needs from admission through to discharge in partnership with family/carer and other agencies.

Named nurse: where a patient has a named nurse, this nurse will lead the process of discharge planning for each admission where possible with the assistance of the nurses who are allocated to care for these children on a shift to shift basis.

Allocated nurse: for all other patients, the discharge planning process for each child is led by the nurse allocated to care for them on that shift. The discharge planning process is further enhanced where possible by allocating the nurse to look after a child on consecutive shifts i.e. by providing continuity of care
Nursing assessment and negotiated plan of care will be undertaken by a Registered Nurse who is allocated to the patient.
Elective patients who are pre-assessed prior to admission for surgery or any other interventional procedure will have a treatment plan/discharge plan in place before admission.
Planning Discharge

All children should have an expected date of discharge written into their notes within  hours of admission, when this is not possible a daily update and plan should be discussed with the family. Lorenzo system must be kept live with expected discharge dates.

When there is no Consultant Paediatrician available, discussion should take place between the named /allocated nurse and paediatric registrar to reach an agreement about discharging home. If no agreement can be reached the consultant should be contacted for their opinion or the child should remain in hospital for a further 4 – 6 hours of observation until there is agreement between medical and nursing staff or there is further consultant opinion sought.
The planwill include the frequency of review by medical staff, and include discharge criteria that if fulfilled will enable a registered nurse to make the decision to discharge the patient.
When primary care nursing services are required for the child and family these will be documented in the child's hospital records, including contact points for key personnel.
All discharge preparation, teaching and planning will be supervised by the allocated nurse, and should be documented in the appropriate places:
Using the appropriate discharge checklist (appendices A&B)
Recording other agencies contact numbers in care plan and/or nursing notes
If necessary collaborative care plan
All parent and/or the carer training, competence and education entries will be signed by the nurse giving the instruction
The allocated nurse will be responsible for communicating all information from the ward; to the individual family and other agencies involved in the child's care.
For children with complex needs, Multi Disciplinary Team discharge planning meeting should be held and discharge should correspond with community start of service for the family.
The parents will be given reasonable notice that their child is ready for discharge home and advice on who to contact in the event of the child needing further treatment/equipment.

Discharge requirements: all discharge requirements should be provided as indicated and provision documented on the appropriate discharge checklist prior to the patient leaving the hospital (appendix A from assessment unit & appendix B from ward).
Discharges Against Medical Advice
Please refer to the child protection team when the child is at significant medical risk if removed from hospital medical care.

Children who are not at significant medical risk, whom the team decide could be safely cared for at home are to be discharged. The discharging nurse should provide the family with appropriate advice, information and treatment to care for their child at home with contact details for advice or re-admission to the ward within 24 hours if required. The discharging nurse should also assess whether referral to the children's community team is appropriate.
Safeguarding

Where there have been issues raised about the safety of a child, the Safeguarding Children's Team must be notified and when appropriate a referral should be made to Social Services. Whenever a FORS referral is made, a pre discharge meeting must be planned prior to the child being discharged from hospital. If there is a conflict of opinion about the need for a pre-discharge planning meeting the Safeguarding team must be contacted.

A record must be made of the discussion and decisions made. A handwritten copy of the decisions agreed at a Pre-Discharge Planning Meeting to be placed on the child's medical notes directly after the meeting and left at the hospital. If an incident number has been raised with the Police, this should also be recorded.
Medicines and Consumables
Medicines to take away will be clearly labelled for individual children with dose and frequency of administration.
The allocated nurse will ensure that the child/family that requires consumables on discharge receives a maximum of 14 days supply and arranges for ongoing supplies.
Information / Documentation given to Parents and Child
The parent and/or the child will be given clear and concise verbal and written information, if appropriate on
Medications – dosage, frequency of medicine
Importance of complying with and completing all treatment and medications
Training and education to become competent in performing specialised care (e.g. Naso-gastric tube feeds, inhaler, oxygen and suction etc.)
Giving of necessary information leaflets on child's condition.
Provide parents with ward contact details and who should be contacted if their child's condition changes or there is increasing parental concern.
Provide parents with a copy of the nurse discharge letter B for Assessment Unit attendances and D for discharges from the ward.
Communication with Primary Care
The community key workerwill be given a copy of the patient's collaborative discharge plan to ensure continuity of care within the community.
The family doctor will be sent an electronic discharge letter, as per Trust policy.
The nurse co-ordinating the child's discharge from the ward will hand the parent a nurse discharge letter.
The admission will be recorded in the Parent held record book if available.
Health Visitor will be informed of discharges of children under the age of five or transfers of children to tertiary centres for ongoing care (contact details available on Trust Intranet).
The school nurse will be informed of any admissions of children over 5 years old when
there is likely to be an impact on the child's education and or attendance (contact details available on Trust Intranet).
Prior to Discharge
The family will be informed if hospital follow up is needed and an appointment will be sent.

The allocated nurse should make the parents aware that it is the parents' responsibility to arrange their transport home from hospital; unless the condition of the child is such that the consultant agrees to authorise transport home.
All documentation will be completed and filed in the patient's notes on discharge.

11. 4 All children transferred out from the Trust must have the transfer checklist completed and filed in their notes and primary care informed of the transfer. Refer to the Children's Transfer Policy.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection control by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
Staffing and Training
All medical and nursing staff are to ensure that their knowledge, competencies and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the trust's intranet site.
Audit and Monitoring
An annual audit of compliance with the following key requirements will be undertaken by the Lead Nurse for Children and Young People and the Clinical Audit Team:
The discharge requirements
The documentation to accompany the patient on discharge
The information given to the patient
The process for discharge out of hours.

The findings of the audit will be reported to the Clinical Director for Women and Children and to the Governance Performance Group. Where any deficiencies are identified, action plans will be developed with named leads and timescales and progress will be monitored as subsequent GPG meetings.
Key findings and any learning will be disseminated to relevant staff via team meetings.
A summary of the findings will be reported to the Patient Safety Group via the Integrated Learning Report.
Communication
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff quarterly via email.
Review
This policy will be reviewed 3 yearly as a minimum or earlier in response to local, regional or national initiatives.
References
HM Government (2006) Working Together to Safeguard Children: A Guide to Inter- agency Working to Safeguard and Promote the Welfare of Children. London, Stationery Office
Department of Health (2003) Getting the Right Start: National Service Framework for Children - A Standard for Hospital Services. London. DH.
